g.text: We followed a similar procedure to calculate the annually averaged modeled
dust AOD for each site. That is, we used the simulated AOD at the exact days for
averaged AOD, which we then averaged for each of the 12 months to obtain the
seasonal AOD cycle. We then subtracted this from each modeled monthly averaged
AOD to obtain the AOD anomaly, which was then averaged over all months in a
given year to obtain the modeled annually averaged AOD anomaly. We then
obtained the modeled annually averaged AOD by adding this anomaly to the mean
AOD obtained from averaging over the modeled seasonal AOD cycle. The resulting
comparison between measured and modeled AOD is plotted in Supplementary
CESM simulations of dust response to future climate changes
future and PHYS-future simulations use CLM4-CN to simulate the response of the
to climate changes until the year 2100. We forced
CLM4-CN with a preindustrial atmospheric CO
NCEP/NCAR reanalysis data set (temperature, precipitation, winds,
etc.), and repeated this procedure until the 25-year average of the net ecosystem
. After CLM4-CN was spun up in this
manner, we conducted model experiments from the year 1798 until 1972 following
reanalysis data, combined with historical reconstructions of CO
1972 repeat cycle, but with climate anomalies added,
concentration increasing following the SRES (Special Report on
Emissions Scenarios) A1B scenario. These climate anomalies were taken as the
average difference between the monthly mean of fully coupled simulations with the
. The 25-year cycling of reanalysis data was done to create
realistic interannual variability in the simulated future climate, which is important
because of the non-linear dependence of dust emissions on wind speed, soil
moisture, and vegetation. We consequently report model results in terms of 25-year
running averages. We used output from ECHAM5, because Mahowald
that this model predicts changes in the global desert area that are characteristic of
the mean of the models that participated in Coupled Model Intercomparison
Project phase 3 (CMIP3). The ECHAM5 simulations were forced with the A1B
scenario, as part of the CMIP3. Since the historical reconstructions of nitrogen
deposition and land cover change only extend until 2005
to separate the response of the dust cycle to climate changes from other anthro-
pogenic changes such as land use, we kept nitrogen deposition and land use from
2006 onward constant at 2005 levels. Note that human land use changes can also
. Since such changes are the direct result of
human actions, they constitute an anthropogenic forcing, not a feedback, and are
thus not included in our simulations. For both the BASE-future and PHYS-future
simulations, the global tuning constant for dust emissions was set such that the
global dust emission rate over the period of 1995
period for the BASE-AERONET and PHYS-AERONET simulations, respectively,
for which the global tuning constant was calibrated to AERONET observations (see

cally, we use the global emission rate as
a proxy for the global dust loading, such that we approximated
which we obtained from the linear least-squares
use this assumption because previous model simulations have indicated that the
modeled dust lifetime, which determines how the emission rate is converted to
loading, is relatively insensitive to climate

to possible changes in dust lifetime is likely to be a small contributor to the
climate feedback by combining the CMIP5 and CESM estimates of

by combining an analysis of the size-resolved dust loading

, we obtained the simulated present climate dust DRE
due to both SW and LW interactions for each modeled particle bin
of location. Since the dust DRE generated by a particle bin scales with that bin

that corrects the simulated globally averaged dust AOD
for that particle bin to the constraint on the globally averaged dust AOD obtained
. That is, the DRE due to SW

. This calculation is averaged over a large number (
is the DAOD predicted by model

(see their Figs. 2c and S1). The SW and LW DRE that
result from the above procedure are plotted in Supplementary Fig. 6 for each of the
We then obtained the regional dust SW
averaging over the SW and LW DRE obtained for each of the
The resulting SW DRE, LW DRE, and total DRE
plotted in Supplementary Fig. 7, and are used in the calculation of the regional
. We list here the most important limitations of
our methodology that have not already been discussed in the main text. First, the
coarse resolution and incomplete description of the land surface handicaps climate
models in simulating dust emissions. This occurs in large part because dust
emission is a small-scale process that is sensitive to unresolved variations in both
(turbulent) winds and in soil properties such as size distribution, mineralogy, soil
. Furthermore, dust emission can be triggered
by mesoscale meteorological events that also are not captured well in many
, such as haboobs and the breakdown of the nocturnal low level jet. These
limitations restrict the ability of models to reproduce the dust cycle even in the
, and thus adds substantial uncertainty to simulations of the
dust cycle in a future climate. Therefore, although we use an ensemble of climate
, it is possible that climate models have systematic biases in
simulating dust cycle response to climate changes, which cannot be quanti
Second, the CMIP5 and CESM simulations do not account for changes in the dust
emission rate due to changes in source regions, other than those already captured
in its physically based scheme. That is, these simulations do not account for (i)
uvial) sediment supply and thus erodibility of existing source regions,
and (ii) changes in biogeography, i.e., changes in biomes rather than changes in
LAI within a biome, which CESM does account for. Third, the simulated response
of the global dust cycle to climate changes is known to be highly sensitivity to both
the treatment of the response of vegetation to changes in climate and CO
centration, and to future changes in precipitation and surface temperature
Whereas the ensemble of CMIP5 simulations captures a range of possibilities for
both future changes in meteorology and vegetation response to changes in climate
, the CESM future simulations do not. That is, these simulations were
forced with atmospheric simulations that are close to the median of the CMIP3
climate model ensemble, and use only a single parameterization of vegetation
. Fourth, the CMIP5 and CESM simulations,
respectively, use the RCP8.5 and A1B scenarios, and we did not test the sensitivity
climate feedback to the emissions scenario. Nonetheless, because
climate feedback is implicitly normalized by the surface tempera-
ture change, we expect differences in the direct dust
scenarios to be substantially less than they would be for model calculations of dust
